awd_titl_txt: Multiscale Modeling and Experimental Study of Defect Formation during Aluminum Alloy Solidification
awd_abstract_narration:
Solidification (liquid to solid transition) occurring during the casting of metallic alloys plays an important role in determining the structures of the resulting materials at the nanometer scale, as well as their mechanical properties. During solidification in a casting process, the liquid metal surface reacts with the environment, resulting in generation of metallic oxides, which are called oxide bifilms.  These bifilms can lead to different types of defects in materials, especially in aluminum alloys because of their high rate of oxidation. Oxide bifilms play a major role in reducing the quality and reliability of aluminum castings and can account for as much as 80% of the total effective problems in castings. This award supports fundamental research to study oxide bifilm formation and evolution during solidification of aluminum alloys. The outcomes of this research will enable practical recommendations for controlling and reducing defects in aluminum casting.  This research has applications in the automobile, aerospace, and other industries that demand lightweight, high strength and fatigue-resistant metallic alloys. This project will also contribute to the manufacture of lighter and more energy-efficient vehicles.

Oxide bifilms are now believed to be the main cause of micro-cracks, microporosity, and other ailments that greatly weaken the mechanical properties of cast parts. While there is experimental evidence that is consistent with this hypothesis, the role of bifilms in producing defects and the mechanisms of defect creation are mostly conjecture, because no direct observation has been possible, the mechanical properties of bifilms are unknown, and the physics of bifilm evolution and interaction with crystalline dendrites during solidification is not understood. The research team will perform atomistic simulations to determine the high temperature mechanical properties of oxide bifilms. These results will be transferred to a new multi-phase-field model to simulate, for the first time, the interactions between bifilms and solidifying dendrites and to track the evolution and deformation of bifilms during solidification. Macro-scale thermal-fluid analysis will be performed to determine fluid flow and thermal boundary conditions for the micro-scale regions of the phase-field model. Casting and characterization experiments will be performed to validate the model predictions.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported fundamental research to study defect formation and evolution during solidification of metals and alloys. In several processing methods of metals and alloys, solidification (liquid to solid transition) occurs which plays an important role in determining the nano and microstructures of the resulting materials, as well as their mechanical properties. The oxidation of the liquid metal surface results in generation of folded metallic oxides, which are called oxide bifilms. These bifilms can change the nano and microstructures and lead to different types of defects in materials, especially in aluminum containing alloys because of their high rate of oxidation.

In this project, we developed a multiscale computational framework to study the fundamental mechanisms of crystal nucleation and defect formation in solidification of aluminum alloys, which was also extend to other alloys. The most accurate high-temperature interatomic potentials for several metals and alloys were developed enabling quantitative atomistic simulation of solidification at the nanoscale. The simulation results provided concrete explanations for the mechanisms of heterogonies in homogeneous nucleation providing a unified theory for solidification of metals regardless of their crystal structure. Also for the first time, the evolution of defects and mechanical properties of solidified structures were determined. In addition, rapid direction solidification of alloys was simulated for the first time by atomistic simulations, showing that at the initial stages of solidification, several small grains, defects, and twin boundaries formed, but as solidification progressed only a few of these grains grew and elongated towards the solidification direction. These elongated grains contained less defect. Deformation simulations suggested that the directionally solidified alloy has more strength when deformed in the direction of the solidification than other directions. Utilizing the nanoscale data, a fully quantitative microscale computational model for solidification of metals and alloys was developed which can predict the microstructures and defects for a wide range of solidification velocity, applicable from casting to additive manufacturing. This framework was validated by direct comparison with experimental data. The interatomic potentials and microscale models for oxides and solidifying metals have provided the foundation for future study of formation and evolution of defects in solidification of different alloys.      

The findings of this project can guide the lightweight metal industries in predicting and controlling the defect formations in casting, welding, and/or additive manufacturing of metal and alloys where solidification phenomenon is a major part of the manufacturing process. Also the developed methods and models can be utilized by different industries to predict the microstructure-processing relations. Lightweight metals are being used in several important applications, including in making of cars and aerospace vehicles. Minimizing the defect formations in manufacturing and increasing the strength of these materials enables production of light-weight high-strength materials for making vehicles with high fuel efficiency and greater safety. This will also significantly contribute in lowering the greenhouse-gas emissions and enabling production of environment-friendly vehicles.

This project provided opportunities for training of undergraduate and graduate students to learn, develop and apply cutting-edge computational modeling tools to study and solve material related problems. Also this project provided opportunities for the students to develop team work and mentorship skills. The Ph.D. and undergraduate students who were directly involved in this project have developed advanced mathematical and computational materials expertise, especially for understanding the fundamental process-structure relations in high temperature processing of metals and alloys. The computational modeling course offered by the PI for undergraduate and graduate students have equipped the students with the necessary computational materials skills vital for solving complex materials problems of the future.
